subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Thorax: ostiolar ruga auriculate, conspicuous. Abdomen: urosternites with black maculae, often shorter than in
N. yunnana
. Male: ventral rim of pygophore with brims restricted to posterolateral angles, abruptly ending (
Fig. 8
A
).
N. viridula
shares this character with
N. antennata
and
N. similis .
Paramere bilobate, lobes of almost equal size; median bristles attached at apex of a short digitiform process directed to lateral surface (
Fig. 10
C–D
;
12 C–E
).
N. viridula
shares the paramere process with
N. antennata
and
N. yunnana ,
but the bristles at apex of the process is an autapomophy. Female: posterior margins of gonocoxites 8 sinuous near sutural angles; basal half of laterotergites 9 concave (
Fig. 10
A
; gonoxites 9 with 1 + 1 concave areas, this characteristic shared with
N. antennata
and
N. yunnana
; digitiform processes of capsula seminalis subequal in length (
Fig. 17
A
) present also in
N. yunnana .
